input_text: INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT Patient: Robert Fields 59/M Date: [REDACTED] Indication: Critical right mainstem endobronchial tumor causing dyspnea at rest and right lung collapse. Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking of right mainstem tumor. Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscopy; anesthesia service present. Findings: Friable exophytic squamous cell carcinoma arising from the medial wall of the proximal right mainstem bronchus causing ~90% occlusion; copious blood-tinged secretions. Intervention: The tumor was mechanically debulked using rigid coring, suction, and forceps. A microdebrider was then used to excise residual tumor until the airway lumen was restored. Multiple tumor fragments were removed with suction and forceps and sent for pathology. Final lumen showed approximately 30% residual narrowing with improved airflow to the right lung; no stent placed. Complications: Transient moderate bleeding controlled with iced saline and dilute epinephrine; no hemodynamic instability. Disposition: Patient remained intubated and was transferred to the ICU for overnight monitoring.
anchor_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
Patient: [REDACTED]  MRN: [REDACTED]  Age/Sex: 59/M
Date: [REDACTED]
Indication: Critical right mainstem endobronchial tumor causing dyspnea at rest and right lung collapse.
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking of right mainstem tumor.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscopy; anesthesia service present.
Findings: Friable exophytic squamous cell carcinoma arising from the medial wall of the proximal right mainstem bronchus causing ~90% occlusion; copious blood-tinged secretions.
Intervention: The tumor was mechanically debulked using rigid coring, suction, and forceps. A microdebrider was then used to excise residual tumor until the airway lumen was restored. Multiple tumor fragments were removed with suction and forceps and sent for pathology. Final lumen showed approximately 30% residual narrowing with improved airflow to the right lung; no stent placed.
Complications: Transient moderate bleeding controlled with iced saline and dilute epinephrine; no hemodynamic instability.
Disposition: Patient remained intubated and was transferred to the ICU for overnight monitoring.
ideal_output_candidate:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT
Patient: Robert Fields   Age/Sex: 59/M   Date: [REDACTED]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
Critical right mainstem endobronchial tumor causing dyspnea at rest and right lung collapse.

CONSENT
Informed consent for rigid bronchoscopy with possible tumor debulking was obtained and risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Critical right mainstem endobronchial tumor causing near-complete airway obstruction and right lung collapse.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Friable exophytic squamous cell carcinoma of the proximal right mainstem bronchus causing severe obstruction, status post mechanical debulking.

PROCEDURE
Rigid bronchoscopy with mechanical debulking of right mainstem tumor using rigid coring, suction, forceps, and microdebrider. Multiple tissue fragments were removed and sent for pathology. No airway stent was placed.

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with rigid bronchoscopy; anesthesia service was present.

MONITORING
Standard monitors were employed including continuous electrocardiography, pulse oximetry, noninvasive blood pressure monitoring, and end-tidal capnography.

COMPLICATIONS
Transient moderate endobronchial bleeding occurred and was controlled with iced saline and dilute epinephrine. There was no hemodynamic instability.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
The patient was brought to the operating room, positioned appropriately, and underwent induction of general endotracheal anesthesia. A rigid bronchoscope was introduced and the airway was surveyed. Inspection revealed a friable exophytic mass consistent with squamous cell carcinoma arising from the medial wall of the proximal right mainstem bronchus, producing approximately 90% luminal occlusion with copious blood-tinged secretions. Initial suctioning was performed to clear secretions and improve visualization. Mechanical debulking was then performed using rigid coring maneuvers with intermittent suction and forceps removal of bulk tumor. A microdebrider was subsequently used to shave and excise residual tumor tissue until an adequate airway lumen was re-established. Multiple tumor fragments were recovered with suction and forceps and were submitted to pathology. Hemorrhage that occurred during debulking was moderate and transient and was controlled with topical iced saline and dilute epinephrine. Final inspection demonstrated a restored lumen with approximately 30% residual narrowing and markedly improved airflow to the right lung. No stent was placed. The patient remained intubated at the conclusion of the procedure and tolerated the intervention without hemodynamic compromise.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
1. Mechanical debulking of a critical obstructing exophytic squamous cell carcinoma of the proximal right mainstem bronchus was performed with restoration of lumen sufficient to reduce obstruction from approximately 90% to approximately 30% and to improve right lung airflow.
2. Multiple tissue fragments were obtained and submitted to pathology for definitive diagnosis and analysis.
3. Transient moderate bleeding was encountered and effectively controlled with iced saline and dilute epinephrine; there were no other intraoperative complications.
4. The patient remained intubated and was transferred to the intensive care unit for overnight monitoring. Pathology results and further oncologic consultation were planned to guide additional therapy and any need for further endobronchial or definitive interventions.

input_text:
[Indication]
PAP, Right side.
[Anesthesia]
GA, DLT.
[Description]
Right lung lavage. 36L In / 30L Out. Cleared secretions.
[Complication]
Transient hypoxia.
[Plan]
Extubate, ICU.
anchor_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (right lung) for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.
Patient: [REDACTED], 37-year-old female with autoimmune PAP status post left lung lavage 2 weeks ago.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen ET tube.
Procedure details: Right lung lavaged with warm saline aliquots of 800 to 1000 mL. Total instilled volume 36 L with 30 L clear return by the end of lavage. Effluent initially milky, becoming progressively clear.
Complications: Brief desaturation to low 80s during large aliquot, improved with temporary pause and recruitment maneuvers.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and transported to ICU on high-flow nasal cannula for monitoring.
ideal_output_candidate:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis of the right lung.

CONSENT
Informed consent for bronchoscopy and whole lung lavage was obtained preoperatively.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

PROCEDURE
Right whole lung lavage (right lung).

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with a double-lumen endotracheal tube was administered.

MONITORING
Standard intraoperative monitors were used throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS
Transient hypoxia occurred intraoperatively.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
The patient was placed under general anesthesia with a double-lumen endotracheal tube for lung isolation. The right lung was lavaged using warmed saline. A total of approximately 36 liters of saline was instilled and approximately 30 liters were returned. Secretions were noted to clear over the course of the lavage.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
Right whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis was completed with approximately 36 L instilled and 30 L returned. Secretions were cleared. The procedure was complicated by transient intraoperative hypoxia. The plan was to extubate and proceed to the intensive care unit for postoperative monitoring and care.

attempts.report_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) affecting the right lung.

CONSENT
Informed consent for right lung lavage was obtained from the patient prior to the procedure.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, right lung.

PROCEDURE
Right whole lung lavage (right lung).

ANESTHESIA
General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube.

MONITORING
Standard intraoperative monitoring was utilized throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS
Transient hypoxia occurred intraoperatively.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
The patient was placed under general anesthesia and intubated with a double-lumen endotracheal tube for lung isolation. The right lung was lavaged with sequential aliquots of warmed saline. A total of approximately 36 liters of fluid was instilled and approximately 30 liters of fluid was returned. Secretions were cleared during the course of the lavage. Transient hypoxia was noted during the procedure.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
1. Right whole lung lavage was performed for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis with instilled volume approximately 36 L and returned volume approximately 30 L. Secretions were cleared.
2. Transient intraoperative hypoxia occurred.
3. The patient was extubated post-procedure and transferred to the intensive care unit for continued monitoring and postoperative care per plan.

input_text:
[Indication]
Inoperable RUL adenocarcinoma (2.3cm) in patient with severe COPD.
[Anesthesia]
General Anesthesia, 8.5 ETT.
[Description]
Navigated to RUL posterior segment via EMN. Radial EBUS confirmed target. Cone-beam CT verified tool placement. Microwave ablation performed (65W, 5 min). Post-ablation imaging confirmed necrosis.
[Plan]
Admit for observation. CT chest in 6 hrs.
anchor_text:
Patient Name: [REDACTED] Anderson
MRN: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED] (Age: 67)
Date of Procedure: [REDACTED]
Institution: [REDACTED]
Attending Physician: Dr. Sarah Chen, MD, FCCP
Fellow: Dr. Michael Rodriguez, MD
Anesthesia: Dr. Patricia Williams, MD

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Right upper lobe pulmonary nodule, 2.3 cm, highly suspicious for primary lung adenocarcinoma. Patient deemed high surgical risk due to severe COPD (FEV1 38% predicted) and coronary artery disease with prior CABG.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Bronchoscopic electromagnetic navigation with microwave ablation of right upper lobe peripheral nodule

INDICATION:
67-year-old gentleman with 45 pack-year smoking history presents with incidentally discovered 2.3 cm spiculated nodule in right upper lobe posterior segment. PET-CT demonstrates SUV max 8.4. Transthoracic needle biopsy confirmed adenocarcinoma. Patient evaluated by thoracic surgery but deemed prohibitive surgical risk. Multidisciplinary tumor board recommended bronchoscopic ablation vs SBRT. Patient elected for bronchoscopic microwave ablation after extensive discussion of risks and benefits.

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
After informed consent, patient brought to interventional pulmonology suite. Time-out performed. General anesthesia induced with propofol and rocuronium, patient intubated with 8.5 ETT. Bronchoscope advanced through ETT after securing airway. Initial survey bronchoscopy revealed patent airways without endobronchial lesions. 

Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy performed using superDimension system with prior thin-slice CT protocol. Planning software id[REDACTED] target nodule in RUL posterior segment (RB1). Navigation successful with 8 steerable guide sheath advanced to peripheral location. Radial EBUS performed demonstrating target lesion in contact position with characteristic hypoechoic appearance. Target confirmed with cone-beam CT showing guide sheath within 5mm of lesion center.

Extended working channel passed through guide sheath. Microwave ablation probe (Emprint 2.0, 15mm active tip) advanced through EWC to target site. Ablation parameters: 65 watts, 5 minute duration. Temperature monitoring showed gradual rise to 85Â°C at probe tip. Patient remained hemodynamically stable throughout ablation. Post-ablation radial EBUS demonstrated hyperechoic changes consistent with coagulative necrosis. 

Guide sheath slowly withdrawn under direct visualization. Inspection revealed mild mucosal edema but no active bleeding. Airways suctioned clear. Patient emerged from anesthesia without complications. Extubated in suite and transferred to PACU in stable condition.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal
FLUIDS: 800 mL crystalloid
COMPLICATIONS: None
SPECIMENS: None sent

FINDINGS:
1. Successful electromagnetic navigation to RUL posterior segment target
2. Microwave ablation completed per protocol with good real-time monitoring
3. Post-ablation imaging confirms appropriate zone of coagulation

PLAN:
1. Admit for overnight observation
2. Chest CT with contrast in 6 hours to assess for complications
3. Pain control with scheduled acetaminophen and PRN oxycodone
4. Incentive spirometry q2h while awake
5. Follow-up CT chest in 6 weeks to assess treatment response
6. Close PET-CT surveillance at 3, 6, and 12 months

DISPOSITION: Admitted to 7 West pulmonary intermediate care

_________________________________
Sarah Chen, MD, FCCP
Director, Interventional Pulmonology
ideal_output_candidate:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION:
Inoperable right upper lobe (RUL) adenocarcinoma measuring approximately 2.3 cm in a patient with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The lesion was targeted for bronchoscopic ablation due to prohibitive surgical risk.

CONSENT:
Informed consent was obtained for bronchoscopic electromagnetic navigation and bronchoscopic microwave ablation after discussion of the risks, benefits, and alternatives.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Right upper lobe adenocarcinoma, approximately 2.3 cm, high surgical risk due to severe COPD.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Right upper lobe adenocarcinoma, approximately 2.3 cm.

PROCEDURE:
Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy to the RUL posterior segment with confirmation by radial endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) and cone-beam CT, followed by bronchoscopic microwave ablation of the RUL target lesion (65 W for 5 minutes).

ANESTHESIA:
General anesthesia with endotracheal tube size 8.5 cm inner diameter was administered.

MONITORING:
Continuous electrocardiogram, noninvasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry, end-tidal CO2, and image guidance with electromagnetic navigation, radial EBUS, and cone-beam CT were used throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS:
No intraoperative complications were encountered.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
The patient was brought to the interventional suite and placed under general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.5 ETT). Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy was performed to target the posterior segment of the right upper lobe. Radial EBUS was used to confirm the lesion location. Cone-beam CT imaging verified appropriate tool placement at the target site. A bronchoscopic microwave ablation was then performed at a power setting of 65 watts for a duration of 5 minutes. Post-ablation imaging demonstrated findings consistent with coagulative necrosis of the treatment zone. The patient remained hemodynamically stable during the procedure.

IMPRESSION / PLAN:
1. Electromagnetic navigation to the RUL posterior segment was successful.
2. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT confirmed accurate targeting and tool placement.
3. Bronchoscopic microwave ablation of the RUL lesion was performed at 65 W for 5 minutes with post-ablation imaging demonstrating expected necrotic change.

Plan: The patient was admitted for observation. A chest CT was planned in approximately 6 hours to assess for postprocedural complications and to evaluate the treatment zone. Further outpatient surveillance imaging and clinical follow-up were arranged as clinically indicated.

attempts.report_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION:
Inoperable right upper lobe (RUL) adenocarcinoma measuring approximately 2.3 cm in a patient with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The lesion was targeted for bronchoscopic ablation due to prohibitive surgical risk.

CONSENT:
Informed consent was obtained for bronchoscopic electromagnetic navigation and bronchoscopic microwave ablation after discussion of the risks, benefits, and alternatives.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Right upper lobe adenocarcinoma, approximately 2.3 cm, high surgical risk due to severe COPD.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Right upper lobe adenocarcinoma, approximately 2.3 cm.

PROCEDURE:
Electromagnetic navigational bronchoscopy to the RUL posterior segment with confirmation by radial endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) and cone-beam CT, followed by bronchoscopic microwave ablation of the RUL target lesion (65 W for 5 minutes).

ANESTHESIA:
General anesthesia with endotracheal tube size 8.5 cm inner diameter was administered.

MONITORING:
Continuous electrocardiogram, noninvasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry, end-tidal CO2, and image guidance with electromagnetic navigation, radial EBUS, and cone-beam CT were used throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS:
No intraoperative complications were encountered.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
The patient was brought to the interventional suite and placed under general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.5 ETT). Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy was performed to target the posterior segment of the right upper lobe. Radial EBUS was used to confirm the lesion location. Cone-beam CT imaging verified appropriate tool placement at the target site. A bronchoscopic microwave ablation was then performed at a power setting of 65 watts for a duration of 5 minutes. Post-ablation imaging demonstrated findings consistent with coagulative necrosis of the treatment zone. The patient remained hemodynamically stable during the procedure.

IMPRESSION / PLAN:
1. Electromagnetic navigation to the RUL posterior segment was successful.
2. Radial EBUS and cone-beam CT confirmed accurate targeting and tool placement.
3. Bronchoscopic microwave ablation of the RUL lesion was performed at 65 W for 5 minutes with post-ablation imaging demonstrating expected necrotic change.

Plan: The patient was admitted for observation. A chest CT was planned in approximately 6 hours to assess for postprocedural complications and to evaluate the treatment zone. Further outpatient surveillance imaging and clinical follow-up were arranged as clinically indicated.

input_text:
[Indication]
Valve migration RUL, symptomatic.
[Anesthesia]
Moderate Sedation.
[Description]
RB2 valve migrated. Removed. Replaced with larger 5.5mm Zephyr valve. Other valves stable. RUL occluded.
[Plan]
Discharge after observation. Repeat CT 6wks.
anchor_text:
BRONCHOSCOPY REPORT: REVISION ENDOBRONCHIAL VALVE PROCEDURE

Date: [REDACTED]
Patient: [REDACTED] "Don" Peterson | DOB: [REDACTED] | Age: 67 | MRN: [REDACTED]
Institution: [REDACTED]
Physician: Dr. Catherine Sullivan, MD | Assistant: Anna Martinez, RNFA

Indication: Valve migration and incomplete lobar occlusion

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient [REDACTED] BLVR with RUL valve placement 8 weeks ago (performed by Dr. Sullivan) with good initial response (FEV1 improved from 32% to 41% predicted). However, repeat CT at 6 weeks showed migration of RB2 valve with incomplete occlusion. Patient noted return of dyspnea over past 2 weeks.

IMAGING REVIEW:
Comparison CT demonstrates:
- RB1 valve: Excellent position, maintained
- RB2 valve: Migrated distally approximately 1.5cm  
- RB3 valve: Excellent position, maintained
- Result: Incomplete RUL occlusion with air flow to anterior segment

PROCEDURE PLAN: Bronchoscopic valve repositioning/replacement

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
Flexible bronchoscopy under moderate sedation. Original anatomy reviewed. 

FINDINGS:
- RB1 and RB3 valves well-seated as expected
- RB2 valve visible but clearly malpositioned in subsegmental bronchus
- Surrounding granulation tissue present

INTERVENTION:
Using specialized removal forceps, the migrated RB2 valve was carefully grasped at the retention hooks. Gentle rotational torque applied while maintaining steady traction. Valve successfully removed intact without mucosal injury.

Bronchus re-inspected: Mild granulation tissue at original deployment site. Conservative debridement performed with cytology brush.

NEW VALVE PLACEMENT:
After measuring, new 5.5mm Zephyr valve (one size larger than original 4.0mm) deployed in RB2 with improved wall contact and resistance to migration. Valve delivery system technique modified to ensure more proximal placement.

CONFIRMATION:
Final bronchoscopy confirmed all three valves in excellent position with complete RUL occlusion. No air flow detected.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Successful removal of migrated EBV
2. Successful replacement with larger valve
3. Complete RUL occlusion restored
4. No complications

PLAN:
- Outpatient procedure, observe 4 hours then discharge
- Continue prophylactic antibiotics x 5 days  
- Repeat CT in 6 weeks
- Close follow-up given history of migration

Catherine Sullivan, MD, FCCP
Interventional Pulmonology
Mayo Clinic Rochester

Note: Migration risk factors for this patient included undersizing of original valve and thin bronchial walls. Consider starting with larger sizes in similar patients. - CS
ideal_output_candidate:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION:
Valve migration of the RB2 endobronchial valve in the right upper lobe with return of symptoms.

CONSENT:
Informed consent for bronchoscopy and valve revision was obtained prior to the procedure.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Migrated RB2 endobronchial valve, right upper lobe.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Migrated RB2 endobronchial valve, right upper lobe â migrated valve removed and valve replacement performed; right upper lobe occlusion restored.

PROCEDURE:
Flexible bronchoscopy with removal of migrated RB2 endobronchial valve and replacement with a larger 5.5 mm Zephyr endobronchial valve.

ANESTHESIA:
Moderate sedation.

MONITORING:
Standard intraoperative monitoring was used, including continuous pulse oximetry, noninvasive blood pressure, and cardiac monitoring.

COMPLICATIONS:
No intraoperative complications were encountered.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Under moderate sedation, flexible bronchoscopy was performed. The migrated RB2 valve was identified in the RB2 subsegment. The migrated valve was removed. Following inspection of the deployment site and the airway, a larger 5.5 mm Zephyr endobronchial valve was deployed in the RB2 position. The remaining valves were noted to be stable in their prior positions. Final bronchoscopic inspection confirmed restoration of right upper lobe occlusion.

IMPRESSION / PLAN:
1. Successful removal of migrated RB2 endobronchial valve.
2. Successful replacement with a larger 5.5 mm Zephyr valve in RB2.
3. Remaining valves remained stable.
4. Right upper lobe occlusion was restored on final inspection.

Plan: Patient to be observed and discharged after observation per routine. Repeat CT imaging was planned in 6 weeks for reassessment.

input_text:
Indication: Suspected malignancy.
Proc: Right Dx Thoracoscopy.
- Findings: Normal appearing pleura.
- Fluid evacuated.
- Chest tube placed.
anchor_text:
Pt: [REDACTED] || MRN: [REDACTED] || DOB: 8/7/1971
Date: [REDACTED] || Location: [REDACTED]
Attending: Dr. Jennifer Lee

Indication: Suspected malignant pleural disease
Side: Right

PROCEDURE: Medical Thoracoscopy (Pleuroscopy) - Diagnostic
Under moderate sedation with local anesthesia.
Single-port entry at 6th intercostal space, mid-axillary line.
Semi-rigid pleuroscope inserted.

FINDINGS: Normal-appearing pleura
Parietal, visceral, and diaphragmatic pleura visualized.
All remaining fluid evacuated under direct visualization.
Chest tube placed. No air leak. Lung expanded.

DISPOSITION: Floor admission, chest tube to water seal.
F/U: Path results in 3-5 days. Tube removal when output <150mL/day.

Lee, MD

attempts.report_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

Procedure Date: [Date]

INDICATION FOR OPERATION
Suspected malignancy presenting with right-sided pleural effusion.

CONSENT
Informed consent for diagnostic right thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy) with possible evacuation of pleural fluid and chest tube placement was obtained prior to the procedure.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Suspected malignant pleural disease; right pleural effusion.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS
Right pleural effusion. Pleura appeared grossly normal. Suspected malignant pleural disease remained the working diagnosis.

PROCEDURE
Right diagnostic thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy) with evacuation of pleural fluid and placement of a right-sided chest tube.

ANESTHESIA
[General anesthesia / Moderate Sedation]. Local anesthetic infiltration was used at the incision site.

MONITORING
Standard monitoring was employed throughout the procedure.

COMPLICATIONS
There were no intraoperative complications. No immediate postoperative complications were observed.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL
The patient was positioned appropriately and the right hemithorax was prepped and draped in a sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was infiltrated at the planned entry site. A single-port entry was created in the right lateral chest and a semi-rigid pleuroscope was introduced into the pleural space. The pleural cavity was inspected and the parietal, visceral, and diaphragmatic pleura were visualized; all appeared grossly normal. All accessible pleural fluid was evacuated under direct visualization. A right-sided chest tube was placed and secured. No air leak was detected and the lung expanded satisfactorily on visualization. The incision site was dressed in sterile fashion.

IMPRESSION / PLAN
1. Right pleural effusion: all visible pleural fluid was evacuated.
2. Pleura appeared grossly normal; no focal lesions were identified for biopsy, and no pleural biopsies were performed.
3. Right-sided chest tube in place; chest tube to water seal and connection to appropriate drainage system.
4. Post-procedure chest radiograph was to be obtained to confirm tube position and lung expansion.
5. The patient was to be admitted for monitoring with chest tube management on the floor. Chest tube removal was planned when output was consistently less than 150 mL per day and there was no air leak.
6. Outpatient follow-up with the interventional pulmonology service was arranged as indicated.

Attending: [Name]
